data.description: Amache, also known as the Granada Relocation Center, near Granada, Colorado was one of ten incarceration sites established by the War Relocation Authority during World War II to unjustly incarcerate Japanese Americans. Over 10,000 people, most American citizens, were incarcerated at Amache from 1942 to 1945.
data.directionsInfo: Amache National Historic Site is in southeastern Colorado about 1.5 miles west of the town of Granada, 17.5 miles east of Lamar, and half an hour drive from the Kansas border. The site is located off Highway 385/50 along the Santa Fe Trail.

operatingHours.description: The site is currently open to the public with limited hours and services. The site currently consists of a cemetery, a monument, building foundations, and landscaping. Interpretive panels and a downloadable self-guided auto tour are available on amache.org to assist with navigation of the site. There is no visitor center at the site.
operatingHours.name: Amache National Historic Site

images.title: Amache Barracks and Guard Tower
images.altText: reconstructed barracks, guard and water towers surrounded by brown grass and shrubs.
images.caption: Reconstructed barracks, guard and water towers at the newly designated Amache National Historic Site

images.title: Overview of Amache
images.altText: black and white image of rows of barracks from above.
images.caption: Amache as seen from the water tower, circa 1942

images.title: Water tower
images.altText: A water tower on the horizon next to trees
images.caption: The water tower at Amache was a landmark that could be seen from miles.

images.title: Gardens at Amache
images.altText: black and white image of a Japanese styled garden with a small koi pond.
images.caption: Gardens at Amache provided beauty in a harsh landscape.

images.title: Sunrise at Amache
images.altText: An orange sunrise silhouettes a water tower and tree
images.caption: Sunrise offers a time of quiet and peace for reflection.

data.weatherInfo: The site is located in Colorado on the High Plains, an arid, windy, and sunny environment. Temperatures and conditions can be extreme in this region, with hot, arid summers that include occasional thunderstorms and tornadoes, as well as cold and snowy winters.
data.name: Amache

data.fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
data.description: In the 1840s the Arkansas River was the border between territory claimed by the United States and Mexico. Located along the river, Bent's Fort was an adobe trading post on the Santa Fe Trail, where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, a reconstructed fort allows visitors to explore the front line of Westward Expansion.

entrancePasses.description:
Bent's Old Fort Annual Park Pass - Cost $35.
Covers entrance fees for passholder plus three adults at Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site. This pass can be purchased at the entrance inside the fort and at the Western National Parks Association park store in the back of the fort. Good for one year from purchase. Non-transferable and non-refundable.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., except on New Year's Day, the Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr, Washington's Birthday, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. During the off-season [October-March annually], the grounds are open daily from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., except for the holidays listed above.
operatingHours.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

images.title: Horse and Mule in the Plaza
images.altText: Two animals are tied to a wooden frame in the interior of a large adobe structure.
images.caption: Horse and Mule in the Plaza

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie in foreground and blue sky and clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Boxes and Furs
images.altText: Wooden boxes and buffalo furs are scattered around a plaza inside an adobe fortification.
images.caption: Boxes and Furs in the Plaza.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie, tepee and wagon in foreground and blue sky & clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Beads in the Trade room
images.altText: bundles of glass trade beads tied together hang from a wooden rafter
images.caption: Trade Room beads

images.title: Bent's Old Fort at night
images.altText: An adobe fort with lights under a starry sky
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort at night

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort in background with wagon in front; fall yellow cottonwood leaves in foreground
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: The Past and Future at Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: A Conestoga wagon and a solar race car stand on a road with a large adobe fort in the background
images.caption: The Past and Future at Bent's Old Fort

images.title: Saddles in the Plaza
images.altText: A row of saddles are arrayed along a wooden beam near an adobe building
images.caption: Pack saddles are at the ready.

images.title: Traderoom
images.altText: A wooden counter is in the foreground of a trade room, with sales items on display in the background
images.caption: The trade room catered to trappers, traders, the fort's labor force, and travelers from the ranks of soldiers, explorers, and adventurers.

data.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures are often in the high 90s and low 100s. Weather is generally fair in the fall and spring. Winter temperatures can be below freezing. Most of the fort is unheated and does not have modern cooling systems, so dress accordingly.
data.name: Bent's Old Fort

data.fullName: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
data.description: Big enough to be overwhelming, yet still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time. Come see some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. Forces of nature and the Gunnison River sculpted this canyon over two million years. The result is a vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.

emailAddresses.description: We will try to respond to your inquiry within one week. Answers to most questions can be found on this website, particularly under the Plan Your Visit menu (above).

entranceFees.description: 7-Day Vehicle Pass.  Entrance fees cover all persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: 7-Day Motorcycle Pass.  Entrance fees cover all persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Commercial tour fee for vehicle/bus with seating capacity of 1-6 persons.  Fee is $25.00 per vehicle plus $7.00 per passenger.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Commercial tour fee for vehicle/bus with seating capacity of 7-25.  Fee is $40.00 per vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Commercial tour fee for vehicle/bus with seating capacity of 7-25.  Fee is $40.00 per vehicle.

entranceFees.description: Commercial tour fee for vehicle/bus with seating capacity of 26 or more.  Fee is $100.00 per vehicle.

entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial vehicles with a vehicle capacity of 16 or greater: $15.00 per passenger (including driver). Fees will not exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per-person rate. Pass and photo ID must be presented upon entry.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entrancePasses.description: An annual pass to Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park is available for $55.00 at the South Rim entrance station from early April to late October, and at Recreation.gov. This pass admits the permit holder and all accompanying passengers in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle to the park. It is valid for 12 months from date of purchase and covers entrance fees only.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: South Rim: 7 miles north on CO Highway 347 from the intersection with U.S. Highway 50 east of Montrose. Physical/GPS address is: 9800 Highway 347, Montrose, CO 81401 North Rim: 11 miles southwest of Crawford, Colorado. From CO Highway 92, turn west on Black Canyon Road approximately 3 miles south of Crawford. Follow the road signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: The South Rim is open 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: South Rim

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day, but the North Rim Road and ranger station are closed in winter and early spring. The road typically closes mid-November and reopens early May.
operatingHours.name: North Rim

images.caption: Black Canyon near Painted Wall

data.weatherInfo: Today's Weather: http://www.weather.com/weather/today/l/NPBLCA:13:US CLIMATE Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 55 to 90F (13 to 32C), nights 45 to 60F (7 to 16C). Winter daytime temperatures range between 15 to 40F (-9 to 4C), nights 10 to 20F (-12 to -6C). Afternoon thunderstorms are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
data.name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison

data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

images.title: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve
images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.caption: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: California

data.description: Colorado National Monument preserves one of the grand landscapes of the American West. But this treasure is much more than a monument. Towering monoliths exist within a vast plateau and canyon panorama. You can experience sheer-walled, red rock canyons along the twists and turns of Rim Rock Drive, where you may spy bighorn sheep and soaring eagles.

entranceFees.description: $25 for a private vehicle. Unlimited entry for one vehicle and all its passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase. Private vehicle must be non-commercial and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This pass is good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This pass is good for 7 days for an individual who is walking or bicycling into the monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Organized groups such as Scouts, Rotary, Hiking Clubs, Youth Groups, Religious Institutions, etc. that do not qualify for an Academic Fee Waiver are charged as follows:  $15 per person, not to exceed the equivalent commercial rate.  Passes are valid for 7 days.  Youth ages 15 and under are free.  Individuals or families in the group may use any valid Annual or Lifetime pass for entry.  Pass and photo ID must be presented.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: Groups entering the park for educational purposes (curriculum-based classes or activities) may be eligible for a free academic fee wavier.  Email COLM_permits@nps.gov to apply for a waiver or for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: Cost:  $25, plus $15 per person to a maximum of $40.  The entry fees for commercial tours are based on the total capacity of vehicles that carry 7 or more people, regardless of the actual number of passengers.  Possession of an annual or lifetime pass, or the ages of the passengers, does not affect the price charged unless the vehicle's capacity is less than 7 passengers, excluding the driver.

data.directionsInfo: Driving Westbound on Highway I-70 towards Grand Junction, Exit 31 (Horizon Drive). Follow signs through Grand Junction to the east entrance. The visitor center and campground are 19 miles from the east entrance. Eastbound on Highway I-70 take Exit 19 (Fruita). Turn south on Highway 340 to the west entrance, which is approximately three miles from Fruita. The visitor center and campground are four miles up from the west entrance.

operatingHours.description: The Monument is open 24 hours a day year-round. Rim Rock Road is only closed for poor road conditions (snow, ice, rock fall, etc). For updates on storm or temporary closures call the park hotline at (970) 858-3617 ext 350.
operatingHours.name: Colorado National Monument

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Daytime high temperatures 70-85 F (21-30 C), nighttime low temperature 30-50 F (-1 - +10 C). Summer: Daytime high temperatures can reach 100 F (38 C), afternoon thunderstorms common. Fall: Similar to spring temperatures, sudden changes in weather common. Snow can occur in October. Winter: Daytime highs vary from 10 - 45 F (-12 - +7 C). Snow common, patches of snow and ice stay around most of the winter.
data.name: Colorado

Colorado National Monument

data.description: Three reservoirs and surrounding lands make up this recreation area in western Colorado. It is a landscape of tradeoffs; natural and human made features exist together. Geologic wonders are abundant from the sagebrush shrublands to forests. Visitors can experience the park year-round on both land and water.
data.directionsInfo: Curecanti is located between the Colorado towns of Gunnison (to the east), Montrose (to the west), and Lake City (to the south). The West Elk Mountain Wilderness area borders Curecanti to the north. U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti east to west.

operatingHours.description: Open 24 hours per day, 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: Curecanti National Recreation Area

data.weatherInfo: During spring and fall, temperatures range from 44°F to 70°F (7°C to 34°C) with overnight lows from the teens to about freezing (-9°C to 2°C). In summer, temperatures are usually in the 70°F to 80°F (21°C to 27°C). Nights are usually 40°F to 50°F (4°C to 10°C). The wind often picks up at 12 pm and continues through the afternoon. Thunderstorms are common. In winter, temperatures usually reach 20°F to 30°F (-7°C to -1°C) and lows often dip below zero (-18°C).
data.name: Curecanti

data.description: 150 million years ago, dinosaurs roamed here. Their fossils are still embedded in the rocks. Today, mountains, desert, and rivers flowing in canyons support a variety of life. Petroglyphs reveal the lives and connections of Indigenous people to this land. Homesteaders and outlaws found refuge here. Whether your passion is science, adventure, history, or scenery, Dinosaur offers much to explore.

Fees for commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicle regardless of actual number of passengers.

entranceFees.description:
Non-commercial group fees (per vehicle): 
Vehicle capacity of 15 or less: $25 
Vehicle capacity of 16-25: $15 per person age 16 and older, not to exceed $60. 
Vehicle capacity of 26+: $15 per person age 16 and older, not to exceed $150. 
You may use Annual and Lifetime passes. A pass will cover the pass holder and up to three people traveling with the group.
Pass is valid for reentry for 7 days.

entranceFees.description:
National Park Service regulations allow school groups and other bona fide national and international academic institutions to obtain a waiver for park entrance fees, provided that the visit is for educational or scientific purposes, and the resources or facilities the group proposes to use support those purposes.

Fee waivers must be obtained in advance and cannot be issued at the entrance station or visitor center.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Dinosaur National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Dinosaur National Monument is located on the Colorado and Utah border with parts of the monument in both states. Dinosaur fossils are only visible in the Utah portion of the monument, not on the Colorado side. The Quarry Visitor Center and Exhibit Hall (where you see the dinosaur fossils) are located approximately 7 miles north of Jensen, Utah. The Canyon Visitor Center is located in Dinosaur, Colorado.

operatingHours.description: The outdoor areas in the monument is open 24 hours per day. Facilities such as visitor centers and the Quarry Exhibit Hall have specific hours of operation. Visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information on facility hours. Some areas of the monument may close in the winter due to snow.
operatingHours.name: Dinosaur National Monument Hours

images.title: Camarasaurus Skull
images.altText: the fossilized skull of camarasaurus dinosaur
images.caption: Over 1500 fossilized bones of various dinosaurs are still embedded in the cliff face including a skull and several neck vertebrae of a camarasaurus

images.caption: The Jones Hole Trail offers remote solitude in the wilderness of the monument.

images.caption: Jones Hole Creek flows year round, providing nourishment for vibrant, green forests.

images.caption: Fossils from a camarasaurus dinosaur display the well articulated specimens still found in the rock in the Quarry Exhibit Hall.

images.caption: Hikers arriving at the end of the Harpers Corner Trail are rewarded with a view of the Mitten Park Fault, Green River and the Yampa River Canyons

images.altText: the star filled sky above a tent
images.caption: Dinosaur's dark skies provides dramatic views of the Milky Way Galaxy

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorns
images.altText: A bighorn sheep lamb stands in front of a bighorn ewe.
images.caption: Visitors to Dinosaur may also see its diversity of wildlife including Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

images.title: Floating Rapids
images.altText: A green rubber raft floats over a rapid on a brown colored river in front of multi-colored mountains
images.caption: Rapids like those in Split Mountain Canyon challenge and thrill rafters on the Green River.

data.weatherInfo: Dinosaur's climate is semiarid with temperatures averaging between 0°F to 30°F in January and 50°F to 100°F in July. Extreme winter low temperatures may reach -40°F and summer highs can top 110°F. Elevations within the park vary between 4,700 and 9,000 feet. Winter snow may be heavy at higher elevations while only light to moderate snow is found at lower elevations. Summer thunderstorms may cause heavy downpours and localized flooding, but fail to dampen parched soils less than a mile away.
data.name: Dinosaur

data.description: Beneath a grassy mountain valley in central Colorado lies one of the richest and most diverse fossil deposits in the world. Petrified redwood stumps up to 14 feet wide and thousands of detailed fossils of insects and plants reveal the story of a very different, prehistoric Colorado.

entranceFees.description: $10 per adult (age 16 or older). Admission is good for 7 days. Children ages 15 or under are admitted free. Fee covers entrance to all areas of the park including visitor center exhibits, film, outdoor exhibit area, hiking trails, picnic areas, Hornbek Homestead, self-guided tours, and ranger programs.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year. Covers entrance fees for card-holder and up to 3 other adults in your party. Children ages 15 or under are admitted free. Accepted only at Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Visitors traveling north/south on I-25: Exit at US 24 West, travel 35 miles to town of Florissant, then follow signs two miles south on Teller County Road 1 to the Visitor Center. Visitors traveling from town of Cripple Creek: Follow Teller County Road 1 north for 16 miles.

operatingHours.description:
The Visitor Center is currently open seven days a week during our peak season.


Winter hours begin in November, with the Visitor Center open five days a week, Wednesday through Sunday. On Mondays and Tuesdays, the Visitor Center parking lot, restrooms, and trails remain accessible.


The Visitor Center parking lot gate is locked daily at 4:30 PM. Be sure to park at the Hornbek Homestead if you think your hike may run late - this lot is open 24 hours a day as a designated Dark Sky viewing area.
operatingHours.name: Hours

images.caption: Walk the Petrified Trail Loop to see fossil redwood stumps

images.title: Ancient Wasp Fossil
images.altText: palaeovespa, ancient wasp
images.caption: Captured 34 million years ago, this ancient wasp and other insects are on display at Florissant Fossil Beds NM.

images.caption: View from the top of the self-guided Geologic Trail

data.weatherInfo: Winter months - average high 40 degrees F; average low 5 degrees F; Summer months - average high 75 degrees F; average low 40 degrees F;
data.name: Florissant Fossil Beds

data.fullName: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
data.description: Open 24/7 year round! There are no timed entries or reservations to visit. The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Stay on a moonless night to experience countless stars in this International Dark Sky Park!

emailAddresses.description: Email a ranger to get your questions answered.

entranceFees.description: Fees are charged only when the entrance station is open in the spring, summer, and fall seasons or when the visitor center is open in the winter season. Fees can be paid by cash, check, or credit card. Passes may also be purchased in advance online through recreation.gov .
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: 15+ passenger vehicle, age 16+
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description:
Motorcycle and riders
Valid up to 7 days
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a commercial group of 1-6 people in a smaller vehicle. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a commercial group of 7-15 persons in a van. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a commercial group of 16-25 persons in a mini-bus. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a commercial motor coach with 26+ capacity. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: Entrance Fee for Bicycles or Walk-In Visitors
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: If you visit Great Sand Dunes more than once in a year, consider purchasing an annual pass to save money. The Great Sand Dunes Annual Pass admits the pass holder(s) and all family members in the vehicle into the park for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.

operatingHours.description: The park and preserve are open 24/7 all year
operatingHours.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve

images.title: Dunes and Crestone Peaks at Sunset
images.altText: Grasslands, large dunes, and snow-capped peaks at sunset
images.caption: The view at the park entrance contrasts giant dunes and snow-capped mountains.

images.title: Girls Sand Sledding
images.altText: Girls Sand Sledding
images.caption: Rent specially designed sand sleds to slide on the dry sand.  Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, and other items don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.altText: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.caption: Elk are sometimes seen by visitors along the park entrance road or County Lane 6, primarily fall through spring.

images.title: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Spectacular alpine lakes are part of the backcountry of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Sand Creek Basin, part of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve, contains lush forests and alpine lakes.

images.title: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Fall is a pretty time to visit the park, with great colors and generally nice weather.

images.title: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.altText: Gold cottonwood trees, large dunes, a silver cloud, and snow-capped mountain
images.caption: Experiencing Great Sand Dunes in the quieter seasons of fall and winter can be a rewarding experience.

images.title: Girl Floating Medano Creek
images.altText: A teen girl sits on a floatation device
images.caption: Visitors can float Medano Creek's waves during late spring peak flow, in years of good snowpack

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures are relatively cool all year at the park elevation 8000 ft. Conditions are most often calm, but winds can arise, especially in spring and during storm fronts. Daytime temperatures feel warmer here year round due to intense high-altitude sunlight, and mid-day summer sand surface temps can be 160 degrees F! Plan to explore the dunes morning or evening during summer. Nights are cool in summer, and frigid in winter. Visit https://nps.gov/grsa/planyourvisit/weather.htm for details
data.name: Great Sand Dunes

data.description: Hovenweep preserves six prehistoric sites built between A.D. 1200 and 1300 which may have served as ceremonial centers. Explore a variety of structures, including multistory towers perched on canyon rims and balanced on boulders. The construction and attention to detail will leave you marveling at the skill and motivation of the builders.

entranceFees.description: Entry fee is valid for 7 days and grants entry for driver and passengers in one private vehicle. Does not cover camping costs.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Entry fee admits one private, non-commercial motorcycle and its rider(s). Each motorcycle must purchase separate entry fee. Entry fee is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This fee type is typically used for bicyclists and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free. Entry fee is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges and Hovenweep national monuments.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Do not use GPS to find your way. There are numerous paved and dirt roads intersecting each other in this remote corner of Utah. The Hovenweep Visitor Center is located 40-45 miles from Cortez, Colorado, and Blanding and Bluff, Utah. Follow driving directions on our webpage.

operatingHours.description: Hovenweep National Monument is typically open year-round. Park trails are open only sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

addresses.line1: Along the border between southeast Utah and southwest Colorado
addresses.line2: Just north and west of Cortez, CO

images.title: Milky Way at Square Tower Group
images.altText: a stone structure at night with the Milky Way arcing overhead
images.caption: Hovenweep National Monument was designated an International Dark Sky Park in 2014.

images.title: Claretcup Cactus
images.altText: a bright red cactus flower
images.caption: Claretcup Cactus is a common plant at Hovenweep National Monument

images.title: Stronghold House
images.altText: a stone structure resting on a cliff edge
images.caption: Stronghole House is one of several structures at the Square Tower Group

images.title: Cajon Unit
images.altText: a stone structure with blue sky and clouds overhead
images.caption: The Cajon Unit is one of several outlying units at Hovenweep National Monument.

images.title: Collared Lizard
images.altText: a green lizard with yellow head, yellow spots and black collar
images.caption: Collard lizards are one of many species that call Hovenweep home.

images.title: Holly Group
images.altText: remains of a stone structure with wood beams on the edge of a canyon
images.caption: The Holly Group is one of Hovenweep's outlying sites, but worth the drive or hike.

data.weatherInfo: Hovenweep is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
data.name: Hovenweep

data.description: For over 700 years, the Ancestral Pueblo people built thriving communities on the mesas and in the cliffs of Mesa Verde. Today, the park protects the rich cultural heritage of 27 Pueblos and Tribes and offers visitors a spectacular window into the past. This World Heritage Site and International Dark Sky Park is home to over a thousand species, including several that live nowhere else on earth.

entranceFees.description:
Purchase digital park entrance passes on recreation.gov at no additional cost. Once purchased, passes for Mesa Verde National Park must be printed or saved on your mobile device prior to use. Connectivity is limited in the park, therefore printing the permit or saving it on your phone is highly recommended.

Passes, including the America the Beautiful, National Parks & Federal Recreational Lands Passes, such as the Annual, Access, or Senior pass may be purchased at the entrance station upon arrival.

Passes, including the America the Beautiful, National Parks & Federal Recreational Lands Passes, such as the Annual, Access, or Senior pass may be purchased at the entrance station upon arrival.

data.directionsInfo: Mesa Verde National Park is in Southwest Colorado. The park entrance and the Visitor and Research Center are located ten miles east of Cortez, nine miles west of Mancos, and about 35 miles west of Durango, Colorado along Hwy 160. Mesa top ancestral sites, Cliff dwellings, tours, and the Mesa Verde Museum are 20 to 21 miles (approximately 45 minutes) south along the park road which which is steep, narrow, and winding.

operatingHours.description:
The park is open daily except for emergency conditions. The Visitor & Research Center and Mesa Verde Museum are open all year but closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years Day. Ancestral sites, picnic areas, and trails are open 8 am to sunset. Some park areas including Wetherill Mesa, campground, and other visitor services are closed during winter.

Cliff dwelling tours are mid-May through late October. Reservations are required and available 14 days in advance of tour date online at www.recreation.gov.
operatingHours.name: Mesa Verde National Park Hours

images.caption: Stop by the Mesa Verde Visitor & Research Center at the park entrance where park staff will help you plan your visit.

data.weatherInfo: SPRING: This season offers a range of weather including clear skies, wind, rain, cloudy days and temperatures from 40–70°F (4–21° C). Snow may fall into May. SUMMER: Most days are sunny and temperatures can reach above 90°F (32°C) . Thunderstorms are common in July and August. FALL: Temperatures range from 50–75°F (10–24°C). Snow may fall as early as October. WINTER: Temps range from the teens to low 30s F (below -1°C) . Icy roads are common. Snow tires, all-wheel drive, or chains may be required.
data.name: Mesa Verde

data.description: Follow the routes of mule pack trains across the Southwest on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail between Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. New Mexican traders moved locally produced merchandise across what are now six states to exchange for mules and horses.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Old Spanish National Historic Trail over the 2,700-mile historic route that crosses 6 states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail

images.title: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: crumbling adobe structure with blue sky
images.caption: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú provided a way station for travelers along the Old Spanish Trail in the 1800s. It is privately owned by the Archdiocese of Santa Fe.

images.title: Rio Chama River, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: hikers walk beside a river with cottonwoods alongside the river
images.caption: This section of the Rio Chama River, tributary of the Rio Grande, is located about six miles north of Abiquiú, New Mexico and flows through the Carson National Forest.

images.title: Sierra Blanca, San Luis Valley, Colorado
images.altText: desert scrub in foreground, spiky mountains in background, clouds
images.caption: Sierra Blanca is a prominent mountain in the Sangre de Cristo Range along San Luis Valley on Highway 17. Locating landmarks were essential to traveling the Old Spanish Trail.

images.title: San Rafael Swell, Utah
images.altText: desert scenery, dead tree, blue sky with puffy coulds
images.caption: The San Rafael Swell is a huge craggy geologic feature (an anticline), about 75 miles by 40 miles, located in south-central Utah approximately 30 miles west of Green River.

images.title: Virgin River Canyon, Arizona
images.altText: a river carves through the landscape, greenery in the foreground, mountains and redrock backdrop
images.caption: This section of the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area is off Interstate 15 about 20 miles southwest of St. George, Utah and about 20 miles northeast of Mesquite, Nevada

images.title: Old Spanish Trail segment, Nevada
images.altText: rocky trail through desert with yucca, mountain in the background
images.caption: This trail segment is 5.25 miles, and is part of the Old Spanish Trail/Mormon Road Historic District, outside Blue Diamond, Clark County, Nevada.

images.title: Mojave Road, California
images.altText: trail through desert scrub with Joshua trees, mountains in the distance, puffy clouds
images.caption: Old Spanish Trail travelers used this section of the historic Mojave Road is within Mojave National Preserve.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of Old Spanish National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Old Spanish

data.description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Pony Express National Historic Trail over the 1,800-mile historic route that crosses 8 states.

operatingHours.description: The Pony Express National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail

images.title: Simpson Spring NPEA rider, Utah
images.altText: A rider in a red vest on a horse in a grassy patch surrounded by sagebrush with clouds in the sky.
images.caption: A National Pony Express Association rider poses at Simpson Springs in Utah.

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.altText: A tall rock buttress with a cleft in the center sits behind a sagebrush covered valley.
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important landmark on the trail in Wyoming.

images.title: Schelbourne Station, Nevada
images.altText: A footbridge leads to a dark steel silhouette of a Pony Express rider.
images.caption: A Pony Express rider silhouette can be found at the Schelbourne Station site in Nevada.

images.title: Fort Laramie NHS monument, Wyoming
images.altText: A tall obelisk monument with bronze plaques sits on a paved pathway in front of a building.
images.caption: A monument and plaque about the Pony Express can be found at Fort Laramie in Wyoming.

images.title: Stables at St. Joseph
images.altText: A large brick historic stable.
images.caption: Visit the historic stables in St. Joseph, Missouri.

data.description: Rocky Mountain National Park's 415 square miles (265,807 acres) encompasses a spectacular range of mountain environments. From meadows found in the montane life zone to glistening alpine lakes and up to the towering mountain peaks, there is something for everyone to discover. Along the way explore over 300 miles of hiking trails and incredible wildlife viewing.

entranceFees.description: 1-Day Vehicle Entrance Pass. This pass is valid for one private vehicle to enter RMNP for one day only. All passengers inside the vehicle are covered. Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: 7-Day Vehicle Entrance Pass. This vehicle entrance pass is valid for one vehicle to enter RMNP for 7 consecutive days. All passengers inside the vehicle are covered. Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: 1-Day Per Person Entrance Pass. This park entrance fee is for individuals, walk-ins, bicycles, and non-commercial groups to enter RMNP for 1-day only. Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: 1-Day Motorcycle Entrance Pass. This pass is valid for one private motorcycle to enter RMNP for one day only. One pass is good for one motorcycle (including all riders). Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: 7-Day Motorcycle Entrance Pass. This park entrance pass is valid for one motorcycle to enter RMNP for 7 consecutive days (including all riders). Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: 7-Day Per Person Entrance Pass. This park entrance fee is for individuals, walk-ins, bicycles, and non-commercial groups to enter RMNP for 7 consecutive days. Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: RMNP Park-specific Annual Pass. This park pass is valid for entry to RMNP only for 1 year. One pass is good for one passholder and may be used in any personal vehicle. Park entrance passes may be purchased in person at the any of the park's entrance stations or in advance online at www.recreation.gov.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Rocky Mountain National Park is located in northern Colorado. To visit the east side (near Estes Park, CO), follow U.S. I-25 to U.S. Hwy 34 or 36 west to Estes Park. To visit the west side of the park, follow I-70 to U.S Hwy 40 towards Granby, take US Hwy 34 east to Grand Lake, CO.

operatingHours.description: While certain roads and facilities may be closed for the winter season, Rocky Mountain National Park is open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: Rocky Mountain National Park

data.weatherInfo: Weather can change quickly in Rocky Mountain National Park due to the mountains and elevation. Elevation in the park ranges from 7,800 feet above sea level to over 14,000 feet at the top of the tallest mountain peaks. Weather conditions can change quickly throughout the day. For detailed weather information, visit https://www.nps.gov/romo/planyourvisit/all-about-weather.htm For the most up-to-date weather forecasts, visit the National Weather Service webpage for Rocky at https://www.weather.gov/bou/rmnp
data.name: Rocky Mountain

data.fullName: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site
data.description: On November 29th, 1864, Chiefs Black Kettle, White Antelope, Left Hand and others were encamped with around 750 Arapaho and Cheyenne people in a valley by the Big Sandy Creek. A hope for peace, brought forth by Black Kettle was in the balance. It was a tragic day where the blood of the Cheyenne and Arapaho was shed, and a painful memory for generations of Native Americans was made.
data.directionsInfo: The Sand Creek Massacre is located in Kiowa County, Colorado. To visit the site, follow Colorado State Highway 96 east off Highway 287 near Eads, or west off Highway 385 at Sheridan Lake. Near Chivington, turn north onto County Road 54/Chief White Antelope Way or at Brandon, turn north onto County Road 59. Follow these roads to their intersections with County Road W. The park entrance is along CR W a mile east (right) of CR 54 or several miles west (left) of CR 59.

operatingHours.description: The park is located 23 miles outside of the town of Eads, Colorado and is open five days a week. Please view the directions tab for more information.
operatingHours.name: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site

images.title: Cheyenne Lodges at Dawn
images.altText: Four white Indian lodges on a grassy plain.
images.caption: Cheyenne and Arapaho Lodges erected in commemoration of the 150th Year of the Sand Creek Massacre

images.title: Remembering the Past
images.altText: A lone tipi frame and two wayside signs stand in a snow-covered landscape
images.caption: A tipi frame is backlit by an evening sky.

images.title: Sunset along Sand Creek
images.altText: The uppermost branches of leafless trees in a grassy plain are lit by the setting sun.
images.caption: The setting sun highlights trees along Sand Creek, forming a hauntingly beautiful landscape

images.title: Tipi Frame at Dusk
images.altText: A tipi frame is silhouetted by the evening sky.
images.caption: The silhouette of a lone tipi at dusk symbolizes the tragic events that occurred in 1864 and of the indomitable spirit of the Cheyenne and Arapaho people, who overcame the tragedy and continue to work with the NPS to preserve its memory and legacy.

images.title: Winter clouds over Sand Creek
images.altText: An expanse of winter prairie with brown grasses, leafless trees, and low clouds above.
images.caption: Winter on the Southeastern Colorado Plains can produce beautiful scenes such as this.

images.title: Snow on Monument Hill Overlook
images.altText: A wayside in the snow-covered foreground with a winter plain stretching behind.
images.caption: This tranquil winter view shows snow throughout the Sand Creek Valley.

data.weatherInfo: Weather conditions at the park vary considerably. Temperatures range from over 100°F in summer to under 20°F in winter. Visitors can expect blowing dust and sand year-round, especially during infrequent storms. Some of these storms produce violent tornadoes or large blizzards, so prepare accordingly, and contact the on-duty Ranger to ask about road conditions at (719)-438-5916
data.name: Sand Creek Massacre

data.description: You can almost hear the whoops and cries of "All's set!" as trail hands hitched their oxen to freight wagons carrying cargo between western Missouri and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Follow the Santa Fe National Historic Trail through five states and you'll find adventure and evidence of past travelers who made this remarkable trip before you!
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail over the 900-mile historic route that crosses five states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail

images.title: Cimarron National Grassland
images.altText: Warm light from the setting sun gives an orange glow to a rock bluff overlooking a grassland.
images.caption: Visit Cimarron National Grassland to experience the Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Neosho River Crossing, Council Grove
images.altText: A wide river with green grass parks on the side.
images.caption: The Neosho River in Council Grove was an important crossing on the trail.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site, La Junta, Colorado
images.altText: emigrant wagons pulled by oxen and horses cross the prairie with people walking alongside
images.caption: After spending weeks crossing hundreds of miles of lonely and desolate prairie, a trading post appeared: a welcome respite where travelers could repair their wagon and trade for coffee, sugar, blankets, and ammunition.

images.title: Wagon Mound, Mora County, New Mexico
images.altText: desert landscape with a mountain that looks like a wagon from a distance, verdant green grasses
images.caption: Wagon Mound was a landmark on the Santa Fe Trail. Coming from Raton, New Mexico, travelers looked for this wagon-like hill to know that they were close to Santa Fe. Leave Interstate 25 at the village of Wagon Mound in Mora County to find this landmark.

images.title: Fort Union, New Mexico
images.altText: A stone path leads into the distance next to adobe ruins.
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail traverses through Fort Union.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Santa Fe

multimedia.title: Pawnee Rock State Historic Site – Place to visit on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail
Black Jack Ruts – Place to visit on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail
Historic Sites

data.description: Yucca House National Monument preserves a large unexcavated pueblo with a stunning setting in Montezuma Valley, nestled between Mesa Verde and Ute Mountain. Since Yucca House was protected as a national monument in 1919, it has remained largely untouched, offering intrepid visitors a sense of discovery and preserving the pueblo's beauty and integrity for future generations.
data.directionsInfo: From Cortez, take Hwy. 491 south approximately 8 miles. Take a right on MC County Road B (green sign), which is a dirt road one mile south of MC Road C. Drive 0.8 miles, crossing a paved road (MC Road 21), and take the next dirt road on the right (before the farmhouse on the left). Follow this road north and west for 1.4 miles, and head towards a white ranch house with a red roof on the west horizon. Once at the ranch house, Yucca House NM is on the left side if the driveway.

operatingHours.description: Open year-round, weather pending. No services are available.
operatingHours.name: Yucca House National Monument

images.title: Yucca House Spring
images.altText: Cattails with mesa in background.
images.caption: Cattails define marshy locations watered by springs.

images.altText: View of Mesa Verde landform
images.caption: View of Mesa Verde above from Yucca House in the valley below.

images.title: Walls of the Yucca House Pueblo
images.altText: Masonry walls seen through shrubbery
images.caption: Ancient walls of Yucca House still standing today.

images.title: Ancestral Puebloan Wall at Yucca House
images.altText: Close up view of an ancient wall at Yucca House
images.caption: View of an Ancestral Puebloan wall still standing at Yucca House.

images.title: Yucca House in Context
images.altText: View of  ancient wall in the center of agricultural land surrounding it.
images.caption: The Yucca House archeological site is surrounded by agricultural land today.

data.weatherInfo: Spring and Fall are mild with daytime temperatures ranging from 50 F to 80 F. Winter temperatures are below 50 F with occasional snowstorms. Summers are hot and dry, with highs in the 90s.
data.name: Yucca House
